body:
Thanks @pepyakin, however that's not the issue here :) . We ignore the FrameDisplayEventReceiver message queue just so that the leak traces are less confusing, but the message queue is still held by the main thread looper anyway.

We can see that a destroyed activity (mDestroyed = true) holds on to a destroyed fragment. So the fragment is leaking because the activity is leaking.

The AppCompatEditText has a non null AttachInfo, so it hasn't been detached from the window which means its activity is not destroyed.

The key part here is:

```
* references android.support.v7.widget.AppCompatEditText.mClipboardExManager
* references android.sec.clipboard.ClipboardExManager.mClipboardUIManager
* references android.sec.clipboard.ClipboardUIManager.mContext
* references .MainActivity.mFragments
```

In other words, that Clipboard manager (which is some Samsung BS) is leaking a context. We already ignored ClipboardUIManager.sInstance: https://github.com/square/leakcanary/blob/master/leakcanary-android/src/main/java/com/squareup/leakcanary/AndroidExcludedRefs.java#L262

I'm thinking we should change it to ignore `ClipboardUIManager.mContext` which will account for other things keeping references to the ClipboardUIManager.

It would be even better if someone extracted the ClipboardUIManager class from a samsung phone and decompiled it, so that we could see what's up and find a fix through reflection.
@pyricau I've managed to get `ClipboardUIManager` from Note 3. But I'm in doubt is it legal to paste it here and where I should place it instead.

> So I think we could call android.sec.clipboard.ClipboardUIManager.getInstance with Application object which should prevent activity leaking.

... tells NoSuchMethodException.
@GRouslan , could you show me the code?
OK will help as soon as I get to IDE (aprx. in 3 hours).
Seems it works! No leaks, MainActivity has 1 instance in eclipse's MAT, memory is on the same level. Thank you pepyakin and leakcanary!

issue.title: Add fix suggestion for ClipboardUIManager leak.

repository.name: leakcanary
repository.description: A memory leak detection library for Android.

issue.body:
Gist with example: https://gist.github.com/pepyakin/8d2221501fd572d4a61c
Based on discussion in #133 

I didn't change `sInstance` to `mContext` as discussed because I'm in doubt. Actually I don't fully understand why we should ignore that leaks. Although, we can't do much about them, but at least we can start to file bugs to samsung (if possible) and treat them separately.
But I can change if you ask.

body:
Sorry for being late to the party!

I have a report on a Nexus 5 device which I find very related.
To my mind, the important bit of these reports is:

```
  * ...
  * references android.os.MessageQueue.mMessages
  * references android.os.Message.callback
  * references android.widget.Editor$Blink.this$0
  * references android.widget.Editor.mTextView
  * ...
```

I think what happens is that the `Editor.Blink` object is being held in the `MessageQueue` for up to 0.5 seconds until the next "blink" happens.  If so, this report is not Samsung-specific and we should add `android.widget.Editor$Blink` to `AndroidExcludedRefs.java`.

// Please note I'm new to Android development, so I might be wrong all around the place.
// I have had quite some experience deploying Valgrind to projects in C++ though, which is related, I hope.

@pepyakin presumably no one is calling ClipboardUIManager directly in order to trigger this leak; so would it be safe to assume that Samsung is probably injecting this manager into the [CLIPBOARD_SERVICE](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/Context.html#CLIPBOARD_SERVICE) via getSystemService()?  Which would mean that simply calling `getApplicationContext().getSystemService(Context.CLIPBOARD_SERVICE)` would initialize that ClipboardUIManager with the application context?  Or do you think it is something that Samsung does outside of the real ClipboardManager, holding onto an Activity context?
